entries.name: Engines
entries: Impulse (3,000 feet): Maneuverability (360)

entries.name: Systems
entries: {@item communications|darkmatter}, {@item hypercapacitor|darkmatter}, {@item life support|darkmatter}, {@item sensors|darkmatter}, {@item shield generator|darkmatter}

entries.name: Crew
entries: Captain, Engineer, Pilot, 2 Gunners

entries.name: Cargo
entries: 4 tons

entries.name: All-Around Shielding
entries: This ship's shield covers it on all sides, instead of one.

entries.name: Combined Frame
entries: This frame is comprised of three to five fighter-sized frames, which undergo a complex transformation process to interconnect into this larger humanoid frame. This ship's melee weapons are determined by each of its constituent frames: it has two of those melee weapons at once, and the gunners can switch which weapons are active as a bonus action. The ship's HP is equal to the sum of all its constituent ships' HP.
The pilots of each constituent ship can assume any of this ship's roles.

This ship is a humanoid battle frame, capable of wielding weapons and taking actions that a normal human could. This ship can walk on land with a movement speed of 2,000 feet. The pilot can use its action to Dash (on land only), Disengage, or Dodge while in this ship. This ship can't target creatures smaller than mega size.

At the GM's discretion, the pilot and gunners of this ship can use actions and features (such as Sneak Attack) they would normally be capable of, as long as such an action is reasonable for the frame to take.

entries.name: Weakpoint
entries: Once per turn, when this ship hits with a melee weapon attack, it can add an extra {@damage 2d8} mega damage to the roll if the target is below its hit point maximum.

entries.name: Multiattack
entries: The frame makes four attacks with its mega laser sword.

entries.name: Mega Laser Sword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 500 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) mega radiant damage. The gunners must have {@item laser sword|darkmatter} proficiency to use this weapon.

entries.name: Ultima Cannon {@recharge 5}
entries: You fire a staggering chromatic beam in a 6,000-foot long, 500-foot wide line. Each mega creature and the pilot of each ship in the area must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw taking 33 ({@damage 6d10}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

Cela n'a aucun effet mécanique en soi ; en revanche, cela donne une idée des types de créatures qui pourraient les piloter et des statistiques que vous pouvez attendre de ce type de vaisseau. Par exemple, les marteaux, qui sont des chasseurs nains, sont construits solidement, et possèdent une classe d'armure plus élevée que beaucoup d'autres chasseurs.

De plus, la table de classification des navires indique la taille d'un navire en pieds et sa taille selon les règles optionnelles de combat en grille. Les tailles indiquées sont des tailles maximales.

entries.name: Character Level
entries: Un groupe d'aventuriers typique peut commencer ses aventures avec un modeste navire personnel et investir dans des navires plus grands et plus performants au fur et à mesure que sa fortune augmente. Les groupes plus importants, cependant, trouveront l'espace de chargement et la capacité d'équipage d'un navire de transport essentiels. À des niveaux très élevés, les personnages peuvent recruter un équipage pour s'occuper d'une frégate ou même d'une flotte entière.

En général, le niveau de personnage d'un groupe n'a aucune incidence sur la taille des navires (et par extension, sur la puissance de combat des navires), mais un MJ peut attribuer à un groupe des navires plus grands à mesure que son niveau augmente. Ainsi, la table de classification des navires comprend également un niveau de personnage recommandé pour certaines tailles de navires.

entries.name: Engines
entries: {@item Dark Matter Engine|darkmatter|Dark Matter} (Class 5), Impulse (2,000 feet): Maneuverability (45)

entries.name: Systems
entries: {@item arcane cannon|darkmatter}, {@item cloaking|darkmatter}, {@item communications|darkmatter}, {@item fabricator|darkmatter}, {@item hypercapacitor|darkmatter}, {@item life support|darkmatter}, {@item sensors|darkmatter}, {@item shield generator|darkmatter}, {@vehicle shuttle|darkmatter}, {@item sickbay|darkmatter}, {@item simulator|darkmatter}, {@item teleporters|darkmatter}, {@item umbilicus|darkmatter}

entries.name: Crew
entries: Captain, 6 Dogfighters ({@vehicle Battle Frame|darkmatter}), Engineer, 7 Gunners, Pilot, 2,250 passengers

entries.name: Cargo
entries: 70,000 tons

entries.name: Launch Platform
entries: Fighters which deploy from this ship can move and take an action immediately after they are deployed.

entries.name: Tactical Advantage
entries: Once per turn, when this ship makes an attack roll and misses, it can immediately repeat the attack against another target within range, rolling a separate attack for the new target.

entries.name: 4 x Missile Barrage
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 1,500/4,500 ft., one target each. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) mega force damage.

entries.name: Railgun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 12,000/36,000 ft., fixed front, one target each. {@h}31 ({@damage 3d20}) mega force damage. This weapon then overheats, and can't be fired again until the end of the ship's next turn.

entries.name: Arcane Cannon ({@spell cone of cold})
entries: Each mega creature and the pilot of each ship in a 6,000-foot cone must make a DC 18 Constitution saving throw. A target takes 36 ({@damage 8d8}) mega cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Broadside
entries: The ship fires a volley from either its left or right side. This attack affects a rectangular area 6,000 feet long, extending from the side of the ship in a straight line. Each mega creature and the pilot of each ship in the area must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw or take 21 ({@damage 6d6}) mega radiant damage, or half as much on a successful one.

Lonely nautilid whorl ships wander the galaxy, searching for a world that might not even exist. When their homeworld of Poseidon was destroyed, the only haven left to the nautilid race were their immense ships, filled with the rare aqueous solution in which they can thrive. Indeed, whereas other ships and life suits are designed to withhold a volume of air, nautilid ships and suits are pumped with water and a cocktail of minerals specific to their race. Visitors to nautilid ships, therefore, need to prepare as if going on a deep dive or a spacewalk before coming aboard.

The design of whorl ships, and the smaller pincer ships, are inspired by the long-dead undersea creatures of Poseidon; their hulls resemble great shells, and their landing gear, immense legs. True to their name, pincers are even armed with immense crab claws, capable of shredding smaller craft in a matter of minutes.

entries.name: Ship Traits
entries: The common saying goes: 'No two ships in the 'verse are alike.' Though any mechanic will tell you that this isn't exactly true, the meld of magic and technology spacefaring vessels employ to cross the gulfs of space vary in thousands of ways. Even ships laid down in the same yard to the same specification are likely to go through multiple refits, overhauls, and repairs during their lives, leaving them unrecognizable after a few years in the Black.

entries.name: Size Classification
entries: Les vaisseaux sont classés en fonction de leur classification de taille, qui détermine généralement d'autres aspects importants : la taille de l'équipage, la vitesse maximale en dehors des sauts dans le vide, la maniabilité et la durabilité. Par exemple, un vaisseau plus grand peut transporter plus d'hommes et d'armes, mais un vaisseau plus petit peut le dépasser et être plus maniable. Les différentes classifications de taille sont détaillées dans le tableau de classification des tailles ci-dessous.

Les navires mentionnent également la race qui construit généralement ce type de navire. Cela n'a aucun effet mécanique en soi ; en revanche, cela donne une idée des types de créatures qui pourraient les piloter et des statistiques que vous pouvez attendre de ce type de vaisseau. Par exemple, les marteaux, qui sont des chasseurs nains, sont construits solidement, et possèdent une classe d'armure plus élevée que beaucoup d'autres chasseurs.

De plus, la table de classification des navires indique la taille d'un navire en pieds et sa taille selon les règles optionnelles de combat en grille. Les tailles indiquées sont des tailles maximales.

entries.name: Armored Hull
entries: Once per turn when this ship takes damage, it can reduce the damage taken by 5 ({@damage 1d10}) mega hit points.

entries.name: Ram
entries: This ship is designed such that it can directly collide with another ship and survive (mostly) unscathed. When this happens, the target ship takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) mega bludgeoning damage, and this ship takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) mega bludgeoning damage.

Never let it be said that orc ships aren't at least effective. Industrial in the sense that they run on gasoline, coal, and other crude sources, orc ships spout smoke and sputter flame as they tear across the sky. These pragmatic design influences are matched with strictly aesthetic ones: an orcish rig can usually be found with attractive accessories and an eye-catching paint job.

Other goblinoids, including bugbears and goblins, also tend to use general orc ship designs, but take far less care with the workmanship, leading to uneven hulls and barely-stable Dark Matter cores. These ships have garnered the moniker "scrap ships", whereas true orc ships are called "rigs" or "rides".
Regardless of the model, a small contingent of orc ships make a ready fighting force, as they are sensibly built and battle-tested in the Warzone.

entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 500 ft., one target each. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8}) mega slashing damage. One gunner can make attacks with both of this ship's rip-chains when they make an attack.

No craft in existence works precisely like a vect ship. Utilitarian to the point of volatility, vect ships abandon all systems and features not strictly related to their operation, forgoing even life-support; after all, vect don't need to breathe, and the exposed arcane engines powering their ships provide just enough heat to keep the pilot from freezing to death. Exploiting their nature as living constructs, vect pilots plug directly into their ships, creating something of a hybrid intelligence, split between the pilot, the ship, and the swarm as a whole. The link is inherently frail; removing the pilot incorrectly or critically damaging the ship invariably results in a ship-wide detonation.

In the centuries following the Night Crusade and the liberation of vect in the galaxy, most vect ships have been decommissioned—their volatility proving to be too much of a liability for everyday use. But some militant splinter cells of vect, often separatists or religious zealots, can still be found employing the designs, which, though inherently unstable, are extremely formidable in combat.

entries.name: Size Classification
entries: Les vaisseaux sont classés en fonction de leur classification de taille, qui détermine généralement d'autres aspects importants : la taille de l'équipage, la vitesse maximale en dehors des sauts dans le vide, la maniabilité et la durabilité. Par exemple, un vaisseau plus grand peut transporter plus d'hommes et d'armes, mais un vaisseau plus petit peut le dépasser et être plus maniable. Les différentes classifications de taille sont détaillées dans le tableau de classification des tailles ci-dessous.

Les navires mentionnent également la race qui construit généralement ce type de navire. Cela n'a aucun effet mécanique en soi ; en revanche, cela donne une idée des types de créatures qui pourraient les piloter et des statistiques que vous pouvez attendre de ce type de vaisseau. Par exemple, les marteaux, qui sont des chasseurs nains, sont construits solidement, et possèdent une classe d'armure plus élevée que beaucoup d'autres chasseurs.

De plus, la table de classification des navires indique la taille d'un navire en pieds et sa taille selon les règles optionnelles de combat en grille. Les tailles indiquées sont des tailles maximales.

entries.name: Character Level
entries: Un groupe d'aventuriers typique peut commencer ses aventures avec un modeste navire personnel et investir dans des navires plus grands et plus performants au fur et à mesure que sa fortune augmente. Les groupes plus importants, cependant, trouveront l'espace de chargement et la capacité d'équipage d'un navire de transport essentiels. À des niveaux très élevés, les personnages peuvent recruter un équipage pour s'occuper d'une frégate ou même d'une flotte entière.

En général, le niveau de personnage d'un groupe n'a aucune incidence sur la taille des navires (et par extension, sur la puissance de combat des navires), mais un MJ peut attribuer à un groupe des navires plus grands à mesure que son niveau augmente. Ainsi, la table de classification des navires comprend également un niveau de personnage recommandé pour certaines tailles de navires.

entries.name: Engines
entries: Impulse (3,500 feet): Maneuverability (360)

entries.name: Systems
entries: {@item communications|darkmatter}, {@item sensors|darkmatter}

entries.name: Crew
entries: Pilot (vect only)

entries.name: Cargo
entries: 500 lb

entries.name: Cost
entries: 800 gp

entries.name: Auto-Assault
entries: This ship attacks with both its auto turrets whenever it makes an attack.

entries.name: Volatile Design
entries: When this ship drops to 0 hit points, it immediately explodes. Any ship within 500 feet of this ship when it explodes takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) mega fire damage.

entries.name: 2 x Auto Turret
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 3,000/9,000 ft., one target each. {@h}7 ({@damage 3d4}) mega radiant damage.

No craft in existence works precisely like a vect ship. Utilitarian to the point of volatility, vect ships abandon all systems and features not strictly related to their operation, forgoing even life-support; after all, vect don't need to breathe, and the exposed arcane engines powering their ships provide just enough heat to keep the pilot from freezing to death. Exploiting their nature as living constructs, vect pilots plug directly into their ships, creating something of a hybrid intelligence, split between the pilot, the ship, and the swarm as a whole. The link is inherently frail; removing the pilot incorrectly or critically damaging the ship invariably results in a ship-wide detonation.

In the centuries following the Night Crusade and the liberation of vect in the galaxy, most vect ships have been decommissioned—their volatility proving to be too much of a liability for everyday use. But some militant splinter cells of vect, often separatists or religious zealots, can still be found employing the designs, which, though inherently unstable, are extremely formidable in combat.

entries.name: Ship Traits
entries: The common saying goes: 'No two ships in the 'verse are alike.' Though any mechanic will tell you that this isn't exactly true, the meld of magic and technology spacefaring vessels employ to cross the gulfs of space vary in thousands of ways. Even ships laid down in the same yard to the same specification are likely to go through multiple refits, overhauls, and repairs during their lives, leaving them unrecognizable after a few years in the Black.

entries: {@item Dark Matter Engine|darkmatter|Dark Matter} (Class 6), Impulse (2,000 feet): Maneuverability (45)

entries.name: Engines
entries: {@item Dark Matter Engine|darkmatter|Dark Matter} (Class 8), Impulse (1,500 feet): Maneuverability (45)

entries.name: Systems
entries: {@item shield generator|darkmatter}

entries.name: Crew
entries: Captain, 20 Dogfighters ({@vehicle Drone|darkmatter}, unmanned), Engineer, 12 Gunners, Pilot, 5,000 passengers

entries.name: Advanced Shielding
entries: This ship's shields cover two of its sides, instead of one. These sides must be adjacent to each other.

entries.name: Autonomous
entries: This ship does not require crew to perform any operation; it can move, use its systems, fire its weapons, and perform void jumps on its own. The ship appears to be guided by some unseen directive and perhaps possesses its own silent intelligence. Though its systems and weapons can be commandeered by a crew, they operate autonomously whenever a crew member is not actively using them.
If this ship doesn't have a pilot, it adds 6 to saving throws it makes against spells.

entries.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the ship or the ship's pilot fails a saving throw on behalf of the ship, it can choose to succeed instead.

entries.name: 4 x Auto Turret
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 3,000/9,000 ft., one target each. {@h}7 ({@damage 3d4}) mega radiant damage.

entries.name: 8 x Pulse Cannon
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 6,000/18,000 ft., fixed 2 × front, 2 × left, 2 × rear, and 2 × right, one target each. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d8}) mega radiant damage.

other.name: Legendary Actions
entries: The ship can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time, and only at the end of another creature's turn. Spent legendary actions are regained at the start of each turn.

entries.name: Full Speed Ahead
entries: The ship moves half its movement speed within the cone of movement.

entries.name: Recharge Shields
entries: The ship regains all of its shield points.

entries.name: Repairs
entries: The ship regains {@damage 2d20} mega hit points.

Wrothian ships are like a thing out of a nightmare. Their inky black shells are almost featureless, with smooth curves that lend them an alien silhouette from every angle. But within those shells is something even stranger: a living, organic interior.

Just as other wrothian technology, like collection vats and brains in a jar, is alive with a kind of bestial intelligence, so too are their ships. On the inside, the chitinous black exoskeletons give way to tough, crimson tissue that lines the walls and hallways. Structures of black chitin form biomechanical interfaces, devices, rooms, and hallways. A stygian ship can nearly pilot itself, but is driven by psionic impulse from wrothian primarchs, who reside near the ship's nervous center.

These ships are nourished by the same psionic energy that sustains the wroth themselves; they are integral to the wrothian lifecycle. Deep in the Black, the wroth inhabit their stygian ships, emerging only to raid planets for humanoids, harvesting them for their bio-matter and minds. These minds are processed into brains in a jar, whose psionic potential nourishes the ships and the wrothians themselves, perpetuating the cycle.

entries.name: Systems
entries: None

entries.name: Crew
entries: Unmanned

entries.name: Organic Design
entries: This ship functions normally in Dead Magic Zones, but takes 13 ({@damage 2d12}) mega radiant damage if it begins its turn within an area of extreme heat, such as near a star.

entries: As long as this ship is within 10,000 feet of a stygian ship, it does not require crew to perform any operation; it can move and fire its weapons on its own. entries.name: Engines
entries: {@item Dark Matter Engine|darkmatter|Dark Matter} (Class 5), Impulse (2,500 feet): Maneuverability (45)

entries.name: Systems
entries: {@item arcane cannon|darkmatter}, {@item cloaking|darkmatter}, {@item communications|darkmatter}, 2 {@item hypercapacitor|darkmatter|hypercapacitors}, {@item life support|darkmatter}, {@item sensors|darkmatter}, {@item shield generator|darkmatter}, {@vehicle shuttle|darkmatter}, {@item sickbay|darkmatter}, {@item simulator|darkmatter}, {@item teleporters|darkmatter}, {@item tractor beam|darkmatter}, {@item umbilicus|darkmatter}

entries.name: Crew
entries: Captain, 12 Dogfighters ({@vehicle Umbra|darkmatter}), Engineer, 7 Gunners, Pilot, 2,500 passengers

entries.name: Cargo
entries: 65,500 tons

entries.name: Hacking Resistant
entries: This ship and its crew have advantage on saving throws made to resist spells which affect the ship, such as {@spell commandeer weapon|darkmatter} and {@spell dark anchor|darkmatter}. Additionally, all ability checks made to hack into the ship's computer or any of its interfaces from within have disadvantage.

entries.name: Organic Design
entries: This ship functions normally in Dead Magic Zones, but takes 13 ({@damage 2d12}) mega radiant damage if it begins its turn within an area of extreme heat, such as near a star.

entries.name: Regrowth
entries: If this ship has fewer than 50 mega hit points at the beginning of the initiative order, it regains 15 mega hit points.

entries.name: 4 x Auto Turret
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 3,000/9,000 ft., one target each. {@h}7 ({@damage 3d4}) mega radiant damage.

entries.name: Starbuster, Variant
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 12,000/36,000 ft., fixed front, one target. {@h}36 ({@damage 8d8}) mega necrotic damage. This weapon then overheats, and can't be fired again until the end of the ship's next turn.

entries.name: Broadside
entries: The ship fires a volley from either its left or right side. This attack affects a rectangular area 6,000 feet long, extending from the side of the ship in a straight line. Each mega creature and the pilot of each ship in the area must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw or take 21 ({@damage 6d6}) mega radiant damage, or half as much on a successful one.

entries.name: Dark Pulse
entries: Each mega creature and the pilot of each ship (other than wrothian ships) within 1,500 feet of this ship must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) mega force damage and, if the target was a ship, one of its systems is randomly disabled for 1 minute.

other.name: Legendary Actions
entries: The ship can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time, and only at the end of another creature's turn. Spent legendary actions are regained at the start of each turn.

entries.name: Fire At Will
entries: The ship performs a barrage. It can make an attack with two weapons or make a broadside attack.

entries.name: Full Speed Ahead
entries: The ship moves half its movement speed within the cone of movement.

entries.name: Repairs
entries: The ship regains {@damage 2d20} mega hit points.

The following ships are evidence of convergent design in action: whereas flying cars, freighters, and space stations are constructed by engineers of every race, the most efficient designs transcend industrial trends favored by different empires. Though an elven flying car might be made of sleek ironwood and a dwarven one would feature hard angles and a more spacious trunk, they're both more alike than they are different, and consequently share the same statistics.

Pragmatic but inefficient designs also belong in this category. The Battle Planetoid, for example, is an asteroid or small moon retrofitted with engines, {@item life support|darkmatter}, and a small Dark Matter engine. Though utterly impractical, goblins, kobolds, and other small races have utilized this design time and again.

The exception to this rule is a ship that literally belongs nowhere else: {@vehicle The Infinity|darkmatter} is a legendary vessel, made by no race living today. Endlessly cycling the galaxy, this ship crosses its breadth each day on an unpredictable course, falling out of void jumps just long enough to charge up the next one. Glimpsing it between jumps is a one in a billion occasion. No one knows who designed the ship and set it on its lonely orbit, and to date, no one has been able to approach and board the ship before it once again jumps. It is an enigma; perhaps a relic of an ancient galactic empire, a visitor from another galaxy, or something even stranger.

entries: Impulse (2,000 feet): Maneuverability (180)

entries.name: Systems
entries: None

entries.name: Crew
entries: Pilot, 3 passengers

entries.name: Cost
entries: 750 gp

entries.name: Open Air
entries: This ship can't fly outside of a planet's atmosphere, nor can its passengers survive underwater or in the vacuum of space.

Endlessly cycling the galaxy, this ship crosses its breadth each day on an unpredictable course, falling out of void jumps just long enough to charge up the next one. Glimpsing it between jumps is a one in a billion occasion. No one knows who designed the ship and set it on its lonely orbit, and to date, no one has been able to approach and board the ship before it once again jumps. It is an enigma; perhaps a relic of an ancient galactic empire, a visitor from another galaxy, or something even stranger.

entries.name: Ship Traits
entries: The common saying goes: 'No two ships in the 'verse are alike.' Though any mechanic will tell you that this isn't exactly true, the meld of magic and technology spacefaring vessels employ to cross the gulfs of space vary in thousands of ways. Even ships laid down in the same yard to the same specification are likely to go through multiple refits, overhauls, and repairs during their lives, leaving them unrecognizable after a few years in the Black.

entries.name: Size Classification
entries: Les vaisseaux sont classés en fonction de leur classification de taille, qui détermine généralement d'autres aspects importants : la taille de l'équipage, la vitesse maximale en dehors des sauts dans le vide, la maniabilité et la durabilité. Par exemple, un vaisseau plus grand peut transporter plus d'hommes et d'armes, mais un vaisseau plus petit peut le dépasser et être plus maniable. Les différentes classifications de taille sont détaillées dans le tableau de classification des tailles ci-dessous.

Les navires mentionnent également la race qui construit généralement ce type de navire. Cela n'a aucun effet mécanique en soi ; en revanche, cela donne une idée des types de créatures qui pourraient les piloter et des statistiques que vous pouvez attendre de ce type de vaisseau. Par exemple, les marteaux, qui sont des chasseurs nains, sont construits solidement, et possèdent une classe d'armure plus élevée que beaucoup d'autres chasseurs.

De plus, la table de classification des navires indique la taille d'un navire en pieds et sa taille selon les règles optionnelles de combat en grille. Les tailles indiquées sont des tailles maximales.

entries.name: Character Level
entries: Un groupe d'aventuriers typique peut commencer ses aventures avec un modeste navire personnel et investir dans des navires plus grands et plus performants au fur et à mesure que sa fortune augmente. Les groupes plus importants, cependant, trouveront l'espace de chargement et la capacité d'équipage d'un navire de transport essentiels. À des niveaux très élevés, les personnages peuvent recruter un équipage pour s'occuper d'une frégate ou même d'une flotte entière.

En général, le niveau de personnage d'un groupe n'a aucune incidence sur la taille des navires (et par extension, sur la puissance de combat des navires), mais un MJ peut attribuer à un groupe des navires plus grands à mesure que son niveau augmente. Ainsi, la table de classification des navires comprend également un niveau de personnage recommandé pour certaines tailles de navires.

entries.name: Engines
entries: Impulse (500 feet; movement only across land): Maneuverability (180)

entries.name: Systems
entries: None

entries.name: Crew
entries: Pilot, 1 passenger

entries.name: Armored Hull
entries: Once per turn when this ship takes damage, it can reduce the damage taken by 5 ({@damage 1d10}) mega hit points.

entries.name: Open Air
entries: This ship can't fly outside of a planet's atmosphere, nor can its passengers survive underwater or in the vacuum of space.

entries.name: Pulse Cannon Turret
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 6,000/18,000 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d8}) mega radiant damage.

entries.name: Open Air
entries: This ship can't fly outside of a planet's atmosphere, nor can its passengers survive underwater or in the vacuum of space.

This remotely piloted drone is deployed from the ship to analyze potentially hazardous environments ahead of the ship itself. The probe has no combat capabilities but transmits everything it sees and hears back to its controller. If the probe strays more than 100 miles from the controller, it loses connection and falls dormant until the controller unit is within signal range.

entries.name: Engines
entries: Impulse (1,500 feet): Maneuverability (360)

entries.name: Systems
entries: None

entries.name: Crew
entries: Unmanned

entries.name: Cost
entries: 250 gp

entries.name: Remotely Piloted
entries: This ship is piloted remotely from a controller unit which relays visual and sensor information from the probe. A character can move the ship as an action using the controller. If the probe strays more than 10 miles from the controller, it loses connection and falls dormant until the controller unit is within signal range.

Like fighters, shuttles are smaller ships which can be deployed from a parent ship as an action to perform a number of operations. Whereas fighters are strictly offensive, however, shuttles aren't typically equipped with weapons, and can instead hold a more sizable crew and a larger capacity of cargo. Shuttles are usually used to ferry people and goods between the main ship and a planet's surface, and make for a cheap and effective alternative to teleportation.

En général, le niveau de personnage d'un groupe n'a aucune incidence sur la taille des navires (et par extension, sur la puissance de combat des navires), mais un MJ peut attribuer à un groupe des navires plus grands à mesure que son niveau augmente. Ainsi, la table de classification des navires comprend également un niveau de personnage recommandé pour certaines tailles de navires.

entries.name: Engines

entries: Engineer, Pilot, 8 passengers

entries: 4 tons

entries.name: Cruising Engines
entries: This ship's sublight speed is doubled.

The following ships are evidence of convergent design in action: whereas flying cars, freighters, and space stations are constructed by engineers of every race, the most efficient designs transcend industrial trends favored by different empires. Though an elven flying car might be made of sleek ironwood and a dwarven one would feature hard angles and a more spacious trunk, they're both more alike than they are different, and consequently share the same statistics.

Pragmatic but inefficient designs also belong in this category. The Battle Planetoid, for example, is an asteroid or small moon retrofitted with engines, {@item life support|darkmatter}, and a small Dark Matter engine. Though utterly impractical, goblins, kobolds, and other small races have utilized this design time and again.

The exception to this rule is a ship that literally belongs nowhere else: {@vehicle The Infinity|darkmatter} is a legendary vessel, made by no race living today. Endlessly cycling the galaxy, this ship crosses its breadth each day on an unpredictable course, falling out of void jumps just long enough to charge up the next one. Glimpsing it between jumps is a one in a billion occasion. No one knows who designed the ship and set it on its lonely orbit, and to date, no one has been able to approach and board the ship before it once again jumps. It is an enigma; perhaps a relic of an ancient galactic empire, a visitor from another galaxy, or something even stranger.

entries.name: Ship Traits
entries: The common saying goes: 'No two ships in the 'verse are alike.' Though any mechanic will tell you that this isn't exactly true, the meld of magic and technology spacefaring vessels employ to cross the gulfs of space vary in thousands of ways. Even ships laid down in the same yard to the same specification are likely to go through multiple refits, overhauls, and repairs during their lives, leaving them unrecognizable after a few years in the Black.

entries.name: Size Classification
entries: Les vaisseaux sont classés en fonction de leur classification de taille, qui détermine généralement d'autres aspects importants : la taille de l'équipage, la vitesse maximale en dehors des sauts dans le vide, la maniabilité et la durabilité. Par exemple, un vaisseau plus grand peut transporter plus d'hommes et d'armes, mais un vaisseau plus petit peut le dépasser et être plus maniable. Les différentes classifications de taille sont détaillées dans le tableau de classification des tailles ci-dessous.

Les navires mentionnent également la race qui construit généralement ce type de navire. Cela n'a aucun effet mécanique en soi ; en revanche, cela donne une idée des types de créatures qui pourraient les piloter et des statistiques que vous pouvez attendre de ce type de vaisseau. Par exemple, les marteaux, qui sont des chasseurs nains, sont construits solidement, et possèdent une classe d'armure plus élevée que beaucoup d'autres chasseurs.

De plus, la table de classification des navires indique la taille d'un navire en pieds et sa taille selon les règles optionnelles de combat en grille. Les tailles indiquées sont des tailles maximales.

entries.name: Character Level
entries: Un groupe d'aventuriers typique peut commencer ses aventures avec un modeste navire personnel et investir dans des navires plus grands et plus performants au fur et à mesure que sa fortune augmente. entries: Captain, Engineer, 4 Gunners, Pilot, 200 passengers (up to 1,000 Small passengers)

entries: 6,000 tons

entries.name: Varied Size
entries: Battle planetoids come in a variety of sizes, depending on whether they were built from an asteroid, a comet, or a small moon. This ship's size can be any of the following:

items.name: Corvette
entries: The planetoid's statistics are unchanged.

items.name: Frigate
entries: The planetoid's Armor Class increases to 15, its mega hit points increase to 210, its crew and cargo capacities triple, its cost increases to 30,500 gp, and its Challenge increases to 9. Additionally, it gains 2 additional auto-turrets (all of which have an attack bonus of +9).

items.name: Light Cruiser
entries: The planetoid's Armor Class increases to 17, its mega hit points increase to 270, its crew and cargo capacities multiply by 20, its cost becomes '-', and its Challenge increases to 13. Additionally, it gains 4 additional auto-turrets (all of which have an attack bonus of +10).

entries.name: Ram
entries: This ship is designed such that it can directly collide with another ship and survive (mostly) unscathed. When this happens, the target ship takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) mega bludgeoning damage, and this ship takes 10 ({@damage 4d4}) mega bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Antimatter Mine
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, deployable 0 ft., one target. {@h}33 ({@damage 6d10}) mega necrotic damage.

entries.name: 3 x Auto Turret
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 3,000/9,000 ft., one target each. {@h}7 ({@damage 3d4}) mega radiant damage.

entries: Un groupe d'aventuriers typique peut commencer ses aventures avec un modeste navire personnel et investir dans des navires plus grands et plus performants au fur et à mesure que sa fortune augmente. Les groupes plus importants, cependant, trouveront l'espace de chargement et la capacité d'équipage d'un navire de transport essentiels. À des niveaux très élevés, les personnages peuvent recruter un équipage pour s'occuper d'une frégate ou même d'une flotte entière.

En général, le niveau de personnage d'un groupe n'a aucune incidence sur la taille des navires (et par extension, sur la puissance de combat des navires), mais un MJ peut attribuer à un groupe des navires plus grands à mesure que son niveau augmente. Ainsi, la table de classification des navires comprend également un niveau de personnage recommandé pour certaines tailles de navires.

entries.name: Engines
entries: {@item Dark Matter Engine|darkmatter|Dark Matter} (Class 3), Impulse (2,500 feet): Maneuverability (90)

entries.name: Systems
entries: {@item arcane cannon|darkmatter}, {@item communications|darkmatter}, {@item hypercapacitor|darkmatter}, {@item life support|darkmatter}, {@item sensors|darkmatter}, {@item shield generator|darkmatter}, {@vehicle shuttle|darkmatter}, {@item sickbay|darkmatter}, {@item umbilicus|darkmatter}

entries.name: Crew
entries: Captain, 2 Dogfighters ({@vehicle Trooper|darkmatter}), Engineer, 5 Gunners, Pilot, 40 passengers

entries.name: Cargo
entries: 250 tons

entries.name: Customizable Design
entries: Two additional weapons and up to 5 systems can be added onto this ship.

entries.name: Reckless Bombardment (1/Turn)
entries: The captain of this ship can use their action to declare a bombardment, granting the ship's gunners advantage on attacks until the beginning of the captain's next turn. However, attacks against the ship have advantage for the same duration.

entries.name: Retribution
entries: When the ship is hit by a ship weapon attack or an attack from a mega creature, one gunner can use their reaction to make a ship weapon attack against the ship or creature. Once a gunner uses this ship trait to attack, no gunner can do so until the beginning of the initiative order.

entries.name: 2 x Auto Turret
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 3,000/9,000 ft., one target each. {@h}7 ({@damage 3d4}) mega radiant damage.

entries.name: Pulse Cannon
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 6,000/18,000 ft., fixed front, one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d8}) mega radiant damage.

entries.name: Arcane Cannon ({@spell scorching ray})
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 8} to hit, range 3,000 ft., 3 rays, roll to hit 3 times, one target each. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) mega fire damage.

entries.name: Curse Virus (1/Day)
entries: The engineer of a ship you can see within 6,000 feet must make a Wisdom saving throw. A ship without an engineer automatically fails this save. On a failed save, a rogue virus infects the ship for 1 minute, disabling one weapon or system at random each round at the start of the initiative order.

The following ships are evidence of convergent design in action: whereas flying cars, freighters, and space stations are constructed by engineers of every race, the most efficient designs transcend industrial trends favored by different empires. Though an elven flying car might be made of sleek ironwood and a dwarven one would feature hard angles and a more spacious trunk, they're both more alike than they are different, and consequently share the same statistics.

Pragmatic but inefficient designs also belong in this category. The Battle Planetoid, for example, is an asteroid or small moon retrofitted with engines, {@item life support|darkmatter}, and a small Dark Matter engine. Though utterly impractical, goblins, kobolds, and other small races have utilized this design time and again.

The exception to this rule is a ship that literally belongs nowhere else: {@vehicle The Infinity|darkmatter} is a legendary vessel, made by no race living today. Endlessly cycling the galaxy, this ship crosses its breadth each day on an unpredictable course, falling out of void jumps just long enough to charge up the next one. Glimpsing it between jumps is a one in a billion occasion. No one knows who designed the ship and set it on its lonely orbit, and to date, no one has been able to approach and board the ship before it once again jumps. It is an enigma; perhaps a relic of an ancient galactic empire, a visitor from another galaxy, or something even stranger.

entries.name: Ship Traits
entries: The common saying goes: 'No two ships in the 'verse are alike.' Though any mechanic will tell you that this isn't exactly true, the meld of magic and technology spacefaring vessels employ to cross the gulfs of space vary in thousands of ways. Even ships laid down in the same yard to the same specification are likely to go through multiple refits, overhauls, and repairs during their lives, leaving them unrecognizable after a few years in the Black.

entries.name: Size Classification
entries: Les vaisseaux sont classés en fonction de leur classification de taille, qui détermine généralement d'autres aspects importants : la taille de l'équipage, la vitesse maximale en dehors des sauts dans le vide, la maniabilité et la durabilité. Par exemple, un vaisseau plus grand peut transporter plus d'hommes et d'armes, mais un vaisseau plus petit peut le dépasser et être plus maniable. Les différentes classifications de taille sont détaillées dans le tableau de classification des tailles ci-dessous.

Les navires mentionnent également la race qui construit généralement ce type de navire. Cela n'a aucun effet mécanique en soi ; en revanche, cela donne une idée des types de créatures qui pourraient les piloter et des statistiques que vous pouvez attendre de ce type de vaisseau. Par exemple, les marteaux, qui sont des chasseurs nains, sont construits solidement, et possèdent une classe d'armure plus élevée que beaucoup d'autres chasseurs.

De plus, la table de classification des navires indique la taille d'un navire en pieds et sa taille selon les règles optionnelles de combat en grille. Les tailles indiquées sont des tailles maximales.

entries.name: Crew
entries: Captain, 4 Dogfighters ({@vehicle Trooper|darkmatter}), Engineer, 5 Gunners, Pilot, 120 passengers

entries.name: Cargo
entries: 4,000 tons

entries.name: Arcane Reinforcement
entries: The pilot of this ship has advantage on all saving throws against spells it makes on behalf of the ship.

entries.name: Scaled Design
entries: This ship's systems can't be disabled from outside attack.

entries.name: Wingbeat (3/Day)
entries: The ship moves 1,500 feet backwards.

entries.name: 2 x Neutron Torpedo
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, deployable 6,000 ft., one target each. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d10}) mega force damage.

entries.name: Railgun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 12,000/36,000 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 3d20}) mega force damage. This weapon then overheats, and can't be fired again until the end of the ship's next turn.

entries.name: Arcane Cannon ({@spell fireball})
entries: Pick a point within 10,000 feet. Each mega creature and the pilot of each ship in a 2,000- foot radius sphere centered on that point must make a DC 17 Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) mega fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Breath Cannon (1/Day)
entries: Choose acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage. Each mega creature and the pilot of each ship in a 3,000-foot cone must make a DC 17 Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) mega damage of the type you chose on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Even ships laid down in the same yard to the same specification are likely to go through multiple refits, overhauls, and repairs during their lives, leaving them unrecognizable after a few years in the Black.

entries.name: Size Classification
entries: Les vaisseaux sont classés en fonction de leur classification de taille, qui détermine généralement d'autres aspects importants : la taille de l'équipage, la vitesse maximale en dehors des sauts dans le vide, la maniabilité et la durabilité. Par exemple, un vaisseau plus grand peut transporter plus d'hommes et d'armes, mais un vaisseau plus petit peut le dépasser et être plus maniable. Les différentes classifications de taille sont détaillées dans le tableau de classification des tailles ci-dessous.

Les navires mentionnent également la race qui construit généralement ce type de navire. Cela n'a aucun effet mécanique en soi ; en revanche, cela donne une idée des types de créatures qui pourraient les piloter et des statistiques que vous pouvez attendre de ce type de vaisseau. Par exemple, les marteaux, qui sont des chasseurs nains, sont construits solidement, et possèdent une classe d'armure plus élevée que beaucoup d'autres chasseurs.

De plus, la table de classification des navires indique la taille d'un navire en pieds et sa taille selon les règles optionnelles de combat en grille. Les tailles indiquées sont des tailles maximales.

entries.name: Character Level
entries: Un groupe d'aventuriers typique peut commencer ses aventures avec un modeste navire personnel et investir dans des navires plus grands et plus performants au fur et à mesure que sa fortune augmente. Les groupes plus importants, cependant, trouveront l'espace de chargement et la capacité d'équipage d'un navire de transport essentiels. À des niveaux très élevés, les personnages peuvent recruter un équipage pour s'occuper d'une frégate ou même d'une flotte entière.

En général, le niveau de personnage d'un groupe n'a aucune incidence sur la taille des navires (et par extension, sur la puissance de combat des navires), mais un MJ peut attribuer à un groupe des navires plus grands à mesure que son niveau augmente. Ainsi, la table de classification des navires comprend également un niveau de personnage recommandé pour certaines tailles de navires.

entries.name: Engines
entries: {@item Dark Matter Engine|darkmatter|Dark Matter} (Class 10), Impulse (1,500 feet): Maneuverability (45)

entries.name: Systems
entries: {@item arcane cannon|darkmatter}, {@item cloaking|darkmatter}, {@item communications|darkmatter}, {@item fabricator|darkmatter}, {@item life pods|darkmatter}, {@item life support|darkmatter}, {@vehicle probe|darkmatter}, {@item sensors|darkmatter}, {@item shield generator|darkmatter}, {@vehicle shuttle|darkmatter}, {@item sickbay|darkmatter}, {@item simulator|darkmatter}, {@item teleporters|darkmatter}, {@item tractor beam|darkmatter}, {@item umbilicus|darkmatter}

entries.name: Crew
entries: Captain, 8 Dogfighters (any; no fighter included), Engineer, 9 Gunners, Pilot, 50,000 passengers

entries.name: Advanced Shielding
entries: This ship's shields cover two of its sides, instead of one. These sides must be adjacent to each other.

entries.name: Autonomous
entries: This ship does not require crew to perform any operation; it can move, use its systems, fire its weapons, and perform void jumps on its own. The ship appears to be guided by some unseen directive and perhaps possesses its own silent intelligence. Though its systems and weapons can be commandeered by a crew, they operate autonomously whenever a crew member is not actively using them.
If this ship doesn't have a pilot, it adds 6 to saving throws it makes against spells.

entries.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the ship's pilot fails a saving throw on behalf of the ship, it can choose to succeed instead.

entries.name: Arcane Cannon ({@spell fire storm})
entries: Ten 1,000-foot cubes of flame appear in free space, arranged around hostile ships. Each cube must have at least one face adjacent to the face of another cube. Each mega creature and the pilot of each ship in the area of a cube must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw. It takes 38 ({@damage 7d10}) mega fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: 6 x Auto Turret
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 12} to hit, range 3,000/9,000 ft., one target each. {@h}7 ({@damage 3d4}) mega radiant damage.

entries.name: 2 x Starbuster
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 12} to hit, range 12,000/36,000 ft., fixed front, one target each. {@h}36 ({@damage 8d8}) mega radiant damage. This weapon then overheats, and can't be fired again until the end of the ship's next turn.

entries.name: Broadside
entries: The ship fires a volley from either its left or right side. This attack affects a rectangular area 6,000 feet long, extending from the side of the ship in a straight line. Each mega creature and the pilot of each ship in the area must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw or take 21 ({@damage 6d6}) mega radiant damage, or half as much on a successful one.

other.name: Legendary Actions
entries: The ship can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time, and only at the end of another creature's turn. Spent legendary actions are regained at the start of each turn.

entries.name: Fire At Will
entries: The ship performs a barrage. It can make an attack with two weapons or make a broadside attack.

entries.name: Full Speed Ahead
entries: The ship moves half its movement speed within the cone of movement.

entries.name: Repairs
entries: The ship regains {@damage 2d20} mega hit points.
